questions:
Cattle Terminology & understanding farming systems

As Butchers, it is important that we understand the basics of livestock farming and the key terminology used to describe both sexes throughout various stages of their lives.

Below we look at the life stages of cattle from calf to mature animals and identify the each stage/title.

A *cow* is a female that has produced at least one calf.

A *suckler cow* is the mother of a calf that is being raised for beef production.

*Dam* is a term used to describe the mother of a calf.

A young female before she has her first calf is called a *heifer*.

A young male or female that is less than a year old is called a *calf*.

A male or female cow between one and two years old is called a * yearling*

If a heifer is born as a twin of a bull calf, she could be born infertile. This calf, would be referred to as a *freemartin*.

A sexually mature male that has not been castrated is called a *bull*.

A young male under twenty months that has not reach sexual maturity, or a male that has been castrated is called a *bullock*.

Another common name for a bullock is a *steer*.
